author: i-only-buy-leaps
body:
In my registered accounts I own a few hundred shares of an S&P 500 tracking etf that pays out ~4%, and a similar amount of a Canada bank preferred share etf that pays out about 5%.

I don’t touch trading gains for any lifestyle expenses, relying on salary alone for that.

I also haven’t fooled myself thinking that I’m some kind of oracle or anything. Right place, right time, right market, right bankroll. Those add up to “success”.

author: TigerKingz
body:
Ginny Rometty has no vision. Her background is in the consulting business which is the problem with IBM. Consulting is a DOA with cloud now the mainstream. 

Her IBM business plan was to leach off the dead consulting business and redirect profits to bizarre moonshots like Watson (which is garbage and doesnt work) and Quantum computing (decades away from even the sight of a profit). 

Should of been sacked 5 years ago when it was clear and obvious cloud was the way forward. Now IBM is playing catch up to even Oracle lol.

author: MushroomCake28
body: Indeed, but from 1965 to 2017 (article was in 2018), he's made in average 20.9%, more than twice the average return of the S&P 500 of 9.9% during that period of time. That's the reason why he's the oracle of Omaha. He slightly underperformed during this bull market, but I'm pretty sure he's going to make all of that back when the next crash is coming (he has a ridiculous amount of cash currently, like 130 billions USD in cash).

And I believe enterprise DB is a more predictable market to take a risk in, especially since everyone who uses Oracle tends to hate Oracle and their predatory licensing.

author: xesus2019
body:
Warren Buffett's track record as an investor and CEO is unmatched. In his 54 years running Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B), thousands of people have become millionaires by buying shares and then sitting on their hands while he turned the former textile manufacturer into one of the most-profitable holding companies on Earth. As of this writing, Berkshire owns dozens of subsidiaries that earn tens of billions of dollars a year, and has a market capitalization of nearly $560 billion. 

Yet Buffett is best known for his skill as a great stock picker, and deservedly so. A massive portion of Berkshire's market value is derived from its roughly $215 billion stock portfolio. One of Berkshire's biggest holdings is Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC): The 378 million shares it owned at the end of last quarter is worth $19.8 billion at recent prices.


===== ======


So how much money has the Oracle of Omaha made for himself and Berkshire investors on Wells Fargo? It depends on what you're measuring; on a cost basis, Berkshire's Wells Fargo stake has roughly doubled in value, netting about $11 billion in unrealized gains. However, that doesn't tell the entire story, including how much value Wells delivers to Berkshire's coffers in the form of its generous dividend.

I worked as a software engineer at a top financial services company for 6 years.  IBM and Oracle make Bank on financial services via support contracts.

Is your mainframe running? Because the 80's would like it back...

author: ChamberofSarcasm
body:
Also, tech has bought back more shares than any industry (in the last few years). 

"from SocGen's Sophie Huynh (this is from a November note):

>The level of concentration of tech buybacks is rather extreme: the top 10 buybacks represent 83% of total sector buybacks, rising to 90% for the top 15. This means the trend is driven by a few companies such as Apple, Oracle, Qualcomm, Microsoft, Broadcom, Alphabet and Intel. We can see this in the S&P 500, where no fewer than eight tech companies figure among the top 15 buyback programs. We still expect tech companies to continue dominating the buybacks spectrum (currently 31% of S&P 500 gross buybacks) but the levels should gradually normalize from the abnormal amounts due to Trump’s end-2017 tax reforms through cash repatriation and the boost to US GDP"  
>  
>[https://seekingalpha.com/article/4317967-sixth-porsche](https://seekingalpha.com/article/4317967-sixth-porsche)

author: mohelgamal
body:
Then one company goes down and you loose a substantial amount of your wealth !! Happens all the time. Any single company can be disrupted out of the market with relative ease and you may not be able to get out on time. 

Diversification is about security, you trade the potential for high gain for minimizing the potential for a high loss. That is why every investor is different, if you are young and have no problem riding out a share that went low until it recovers then that’s great, you should take risks. 

But when you really need your money, like a person who is living off a retirement account, and have to sell shares to live then concentrating your money would not be a great idea. Even a temporary low in the company price can cause a significant loss of money. 

That is why they call Warren Buffet “the oracle of Omaha” and “the greatest investor alive”. His reputation isn’t about taking the correct gamble, but about making a steady solid progress regardless of the circumstances

author: cyy-bg-bb
body:
True. AWS has been subsidising it’s main business, the online retailer. Didn’t mention it in my short post about the online retailing site because it was in response to the other comment about Amazon’s impact on the public. 

As you may well know, AWS’s advantage may be slowly eroding as Microsoft wins the biggest tech military contract ever from AWS, meaning that it may develop capabilities to rival AWS’s current dominance. This space is evolving fast. A decade ago Oracle was dominating this space, and it only took a few years for AWS to beat them. Microsoft may very well do the same to AWS as the tech race continues in the cloud computing sector. 

That being said, it is undeniable that AWS’s current dominance is a strong moat. But imo I believe the market is right in valuing Apple over Amazon taking into account the hundreds of factors on the table.

author: HotStockSlinger
body: Just look at earningwhispers or the calendars posted here a week or 2 out and just know which ones will have super high IV and buy which way you'd think it will go on a decent entry beforehand then sell day before to take gains. That or wait until the day before and sell spreads if you don't think the stock will swing too crazy and take advantage of IV crush. Don't have to be an oracle.

author: rajivchaudri
body: Oracle still owns 95% of the US enterprise database market.  NO SQL hasn't been able to penetrate enterprise until recently... so keep an eye on MongoDB as a cloud database provider that  can disrupt Oracle's dominance.  They're growing revenues at about 50% YoY.

author: rajivchaudri
body: I think we're talking about 2 things here.  MySQL does have a large presence in enterprise, but it open source and generates negligible revenue (50MM?) compared to Oracle (40BB).

author: Rageoftheage
body:
That's true but you also have to consider that a huge chunk of hotel revenue is business-to-business contracts for upper level employees and conferences. They can also provide a level of consistency and amenities that you can't get from AirBnB. Currently we are adding value by focusing on data analytics for our franchisees and owning as much of our own tech stack and data as possible so that hotel owners pay us instead of companies like Oracle.

This may not hold true for budget brands but my company focuses on the upper scale segment with only one brand being mid-range(and its still high quality for its segment I might add)

author: DeliciouslyUnaware
body:
So SQ bought me a car but pypl plays bought me a $116k retirement fund. 

If you're new to pypl's earnings month heres the play: long pypl until Jan 20th then go with atm puts because it sells off into earnings every time. 

Dont hold anything through earnings. IV crush is brutal on this and the real rally/dips happen the following week.

Go long on calls Jan 31 and rise the wave.

Collect your tendies and toss a coin to your TA autist DeliciouslyUnaware.

Your Welcome.

author: Rageoftheage
body:
AI programs that will be used to trade securities need to consume massive amounts of data in order to learn and fine-tune themselves along with spotting emerging trends. Exchanges will own some of the most valuable data and analytics companies will get paid fortunes to process it. That's my rough draft of the future anyways.  


You can go to [dividend.com](https://dividend.com) and check the information on those stocks. SQ and PYPL dont pay dividends but all of the others do and they all have been increasing dividends consistently while still maintaining low p/e ratios. In the future shares bought now will most likely not only grow a great deal in nav price but also be paying massive dividends(think 100%+) on cost.

author: Looksking
body: Secular growth companies with a strong product or service based on growing themes. Today? AI/machine learning, rise of the middle class in the East ( think banks, insurance, consumer staples), robotics, healthcare. Companies such as Microsoft, Paypal, Unilever, Google, Twilio, Appen,  prefer companies with a ROIC > WACC, diversify, hold positions in different sectors. Expect to make some mistakes.

author: rjm101
body:
>How do you deal with issues of fraud or theft?

Some people pay through paypal. thesilverforum has feedback like ebay so you can check their trade history.

Yes of course a dealer is going to be more trusted however there are plenty of regulars on the forum that have done a lot of trades for me to trust them but of course it's never going to be completely risk free. The price you pay is how much risk you're willing to take like with most things in the market. I've worked on getting a good track record for my trade history so that when I go to sell my precious metals I can provide some confidence to the buyer.

author: MarblesEye
body:
I stick to a very few stocks that I trade options on. I like to trade stocks I am familiar with and I listen to the news and try and capitalize on a company’s success or failures.  I only buy options. 

At the start of the year I was into financial payment processors and traded. VISA, PAYPAL , MASTERCARD

The last few quarters I only traded Tesla, Apple, SPY and Disney iv alway trades ROKU up until there was a big sell off. 

On my chart the periods that are flat I didn’t trade much or withdraw my profits. And most of the big down draws we’re options that I had 3-5 month out expiration and they had a big down draw. Eventually sticking it out some came back. 

The last down draw was me buying a Put option on Tesla after watching the CyberTruck reveal. The good news is it dropped and I was in the green. Bad news is I was banned from day trading and couldn’t pull out as it started to go back up in the same day. 


Currently I am holding Apple Calls that are doing very well. 


Was unsure how to post text in the post.

author: CowboyJimador
body:
You see payment apps equivalent to Venmo/Cashapp/Paypal in Asia that have really taken hold. For example, small street vendors are unable to take direct card payments, but an increasing number now accept direct payments via mobile payment apps.

I am not sure whether this model is applicable to more developed countries in the West. I can potentially see an expansion of Apple Pay/Facebook Pay to support direct consumer to firm payments without using debit/credit cards.

author: mark0fo
body:
One observation I've made over the years is that questions about leveraging and enthusiasm for it seem to peak on Internet message boards around the times of market tops.

Leverage is great -- if you do it when nobody else is.  Or into assets that nobody else likes.  Hardly something you can say at least with respect to MSFT QCOM, etc.

author: Smart202020
body: Theta always kills me mid-day when I think I'm buying the lows.  I've gotten to the point where I only buy either at the very beginning of the day, or very end.  Buying in the afternoon always screws me.  It happens the worst on stocks like Disney, where all the option value is priced in at the very beginning of the day.  When traders realize Disney isn't going to move that day, those options lose a ton of value even though the stock price doesn't move much at all.  You can think you are buying a low at 1:30, but the option value will continue to drop until EOD.  On stocks like Disney and QCOM, i mostly buy EOD, and sell next day at open.

author: xlynx
body:
All these except DIS are highly inflated and at above average risk of a correction in 2020.

TSLA, as a highly volatile and speculative stock which has just experienced a bout of sudden unprecedented growth, is anything but "safe".

Your least risky bets: 

* MSFT and DIS for valuation. 
* APPL and MSFT for potential long term growth. 

You might be better off with a technology index ETF like VGT and/or SMH for a short timeline like 1 year.

Have you considered TSM? They manufacture chips for AMD, Apple, Qualcomm, NVIDIA. It seems undervalued once you factor in anticipated growth and the high dividend. The memory manufacturer, MU is also hot right now.

author: alwayswashere
body:
the stock price has come a long way. and you could have said the same thing when it grew to $5. and then $10, $20... and you would have continued to be short sighted as you are being now. data and compute appetite are growing at an astonishing rate at a consistent pace ever since we started storing and processing bits decades ago and its not going to slow down.

Lisa has shown that AMD has a consistent roadmap to consistently demolish intel CPU for at least another 2-3 years. after that, i trust AMD will not shoot themselves in the foot again with a risky new arch like bulldozer was. at worst case intel will only catch up.

another major factor here is foundry (node) advantage. unless intel can overtake TSMC (and samsung... and all the other foundrys) they wont surpass AMD. the best they can do is dump their foundry and outsource to TSMC. its just not possible for intel to spend what TSMC can on node R&D. TSMC is effectively a factor of the R&D budgets from apple, qualcomm, nvidia, amd, mediatek, marvell, broadcom, xlinix, huawei...

if you have the vision to realize what AMD can and most likely will accomplish, you would buy in at these levels without hesitation. if you are running a fund... the big and smart money... you are not interested in day trading. they want a nice stock that will have consistent growth for a minimum of two years. a growth company. they want an industry that is expanding. they are not looking at the past, they are looking forward to 2+ years ("TTM PE" vs "forward PE"), to when earnings will be around $5/share (at this rate) from a dominant company with almost zero debit and the best track recordd of any stock over the last two years.

all aboard! (reposted from /r/amd_stock cause it fits here)
